elements.title: Incentive Compensation and Payment of Dividends

data.value: Federal banking agencies have issued guidance on incentive compensation policies to ensure that they do not encourage excessive risk-taking.
Incentive compensation arrangements should not encourage risk-taking beyond the ability to manage risks.
The Federal Reserve reviews incentive compensation arrangements in banking organizations.
In October 2022, the SEC adopted a final rule on clawback of excess incentive-based compensation.
A bank holding company must act as a source of strength for its subsidiary banks.
The Federal Reserve states dividends should generally only be paid if net income suffices.
Company may not pay dividends if it cannot meet its debts or if total assets would be less than liabilities.

elements.title: Accounting Policies – Capitalization, Depreciation and Amortization

data.value: Fees charged by the Bank, including direct loan origination costs, are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loans or estimated life for demand loans. Net fees related to standby letters of credit are recognized over the commitment period.

Land, premises and equipment are carried at cost, with premises and equipment stated at cost less accumulated depreciation/amortization. Depreciation is computed on a straight-line basis over estimated useful lives ranging from 3 to 39 years, with leasehold improvements amortized over the shorter of the lease term or improvement life. Construction in progress is reclassified and depreciated once placed in service.

New product development costs for software are capitalized from the establishment of technological feasibility until the product is ready for general availability, evaluated annually for impairment, and amortized on a straight-line basis.

An asset and liability approach is used to account for income taxes, where deferred tax assets and liabilities arise from differences in financial statement and tax bases. Tax positions are recognized based on a more-likely-than-not standard, with excess benefits reported as liabilities for unrecognized tax benefits.

Components of comprehensive income include both recognized and certain unrealized gains and losses, with specific items such as available-for-sale securities reported separately in equity alongside net income.

Stock-based compensation is measured using the grant date fair value and recognized over the service period (vesting period). For graded-vesting awards, costs are recorded on a straight-line basis, with models like Black-Scholes applied for stock options.

Earnings per share are computed in accordance with FASB ASC 260 using weighted average common shares outstanding. Diluted EPS includes adjustments for potential stock-based dilutive instruments, although no stock options were outstanding as of the year-end dates.

elements.title: Capital Position, Lending and Risk Management Overview

data.value: Emphasizes understanding banking needs and building long-term relationships to enhance funding and lending stability.

Uses rigorous underwriting and credit administration standards. Credits between $250,000 and $750,000 require senior lender concurrence; credits over $750,000 require full consensus from higher management.

As of December 31, 2022, the Bank maintained a Tier 1 leverage capital ratio of 15.05%, a Common Equity Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio of 15.47%, and a total risk-based capital ratio of 16.27%, exceeding regulatory guidelines.
Invested in advanced core operating systems and partnered with leading providers for internet, mobile, and application-based banking, plus participation in a broad international ATM network.
Focused on organic growth via online/mobile banking, strategic branch expansion, and potential acquisition opportunities following rigorous due diligence.
Primary market focus includes loans to small businesses, professionals, and various real estate financings (owner-occupied and investment commercial real estate).
Conducts quarterly stress tests on various loan portfolios (commercial business, residential real estate, construction lending, etc.) to assess potential losses against the capital profile.

data.value: This table presents selected financial condition data comparing years 2022 and 2021 (in thousands). Notable observations include: total assets increased from $1.65B to $1.93B, total deposits grew from $1.41B to $1.51B, and stockholders' equity rose from $188.8M to $198.3M. The institution significantly increased its subordinated debt from $29.3M to $72.2M and added $100M in FHLB advances in 2022. Cash and cash equivalents improved from $93.2M to $130.6M.

elements.title: Funding Activities & Deposits Analysis

data.value: Deposits are the primary source of funds along with brokered deposits, scheduled payments, prepayments, maturities from loan and investment portfolios, FHLB advances, other secured borrowings, federal funds purchased, short-term borrowed funds, and longer-term debt issued through capital markets.

Total deposits increased by $100.9 million from December 31, 2021 to December 31, 2022. The increase was mainly driven by non-interest bearing demand deposits and time deposits, partially offset by a decrease in money market deposits.

Key deposit types include Interest-bearing demand, Money market, Savings and NOW, Time deposits, Non-interest bearing demand, and Total deposits. Notable shifts include a decrease in money market deposits (from 22.93% to 9.37%) and an increase in time deposits (from 34.28% to 43.93%).
Increased from 0.60% in 2021 to 0.72% in 2022, reflecting changes in funding costs.

At December 31, 2022, the Company had $486.9 million in total deposits above the FDIC insurance limit of $250,000. Certificates of deposit in excess of this limit totaled approximately $331.3 million.

Maturity periods include: 'Three months or less' ($113,962k), 'Over three through six months' ($93,817k), 'Over six through twelve months' ($85,494k), 'Over twelve months through three years' ($37,984k), and 'Over three years' (not specified), with a total of $331,257k.
Increase in non-interest bearing deposits is attributed to company-wide efforts to replace higher cost funds with sticky, lower cost deposit accounts.

elements.title: Financial Disclosures: Accounting Policies and Revenue Recognition

data.value: The Bank engages in off-balance sheet financial instruments such as credit commitments, commercial letters of credit, and standby letters of credit. These instruments are recorded when funded or when related fees are incurred or received.
Advertising and marketing costs are expensed as incurred.

The financial statements require management to make estimates and assumptions affecting asset and liability values as well as income and expenses. Critical accounting policies include allowances for loan losses, fair value measurement of financial instruments, and derivative financial instruments, which involve significant judgment.

Fair values are estimated using relevant market information and other assumptions. The estimates involve uncertainties, and changes in assumptions or market conditions could significantly affect the reported values.

Derivatives, including interest rate swaps with loan customers and dealer counterparties, are recognized at fair value as either assets or liabilities. Adjustments for unrealized gains and losses are reported as noninterest income or expense.

Transfers are accounted for as sales when the Bank surrenders control over the assets, which is determined by isolation of the assets, transfer of control rights, and absence of repurchase agreements.

Most revenue from financial instruments (interest income, gains/losses on securities and derivatives) is outside the scope of ASC Topic 606. However, service charges and fees (e.g., overdraft, account maintenance, transaction-based fees, and interchange income) that fall under ASC Topic 606 are recognized when the performance obligation is satisfied.

elements.title: Impact of Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements

data.value: Adopted as of January 1, 2023. The standard requires measuring expected credit losses for financial assets carried at amortized cost using historical experience, current conditions, and reasonable forecasts.

Impact recorded to retained earnings, net of deferred income taxes; adjustments to the allowance for credit losses on loans and reserve for unfunded loan commitments were not significant compared to December 31, 2022.

Uses a third-party model employing a weighted average remaining life methodology; loan portfolio is segmented based on similar risk characteristics with qualitative adjustment factors such as lending practices, local economics, portfolio composition, employee experience, credit quality indicators, collateral, concentrations, and external factors.

Incorporates amendments from ASU 2020-04 and ASU 2021-01 addressing the transition from LIBOR, including optional expedients for contract modifications and hedge accounting, and discontinuation of LIBOR as a primary rate reference.
Adopted upon addition to the FASB Codification with no expected material impact on the consolidated financial statements.

elements.title: Adoption of CECL Model and Its Impact on Credit Loss Allowance & Investment Securities Valuation

data.value: Applies to measurement of credit losses on financial assets (loan receivables, held-to-debt securities) and off-balance sheet exposures. Estimates lifetime expected credit losses using a blend of economic forecasts for a six-month period then historical losses over one year.
Guidance effective for periods beginning after December 15, 2022; adopted January 1, 2023
One-time cumulative effect adjustment to retained earnings on January 1, 2023

elements.title: Fair Value Measurement

data.value: The fair value is based on observable (market data) or unobservable inputs (Bank’s assumptions) divided into Level 1, Level 2, and Level 3.
Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets.
Observable inputs including quoted prices for similar assets.
Model-based techniques using unobservable inputs.
Recorded at fair value based on market prices (Level 1) or valuation techniques (Level 2).
Entire portfolio considered Level 2, except one subordinated debt security.
Recognized at fair value using standard valuation techniques, classified as Level 2.

elements.title: Disclosures on Legal Proceedings, Dividend Policy and Equity Compensation

data.value: The Company is party to various litigation matters incidental to its ordinary business operations. Management believes that individually or in aggregate these proceedings will not have a material adverse impact on operations or financial condition.

Common stockholders are entitled to receive dividends only when declared by the Board of Directors out of funds legally available for dividends. Dividend payments depend on factors such as receipt of dividends from the Bank, economic conditions, financial condition, cash flow, debt obligations, and regulatory restrictions.

During the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022, four cash dividends were declared and paid. Preferred stockholders maintain priority dividend rights with 28,750 shares outstanding as of December 31, 2022.

elements.title: Commercial Real Estate Lending and Credit Policies

data.value: Financing for owner-occupied and investment commercial real estate; 14.3% of loan portfolio for owner-occupied and 29.5% for investment as of December 31, 2022

Underwriting policies focus on the borrower’s repayment ability and underlying real estate; risks include sudden or gradual drops in property values and changes in the economic climate; mitigated by strict loan-to-value standards
Predominantly residential loans with short durations; includes construction financing with a permanent loan take-out; stress-tested using the percentage completion method
Consumer-oriented residential loans for purchase and refinancing, most of which are brokered to the secondary market
Broad array of consumer loans including term loans and overdraft protection
Comprehensive lending policy with well-defined risk tolerance and underwriting standards; portfolio is closely monitored and subject to independent credit reviews
Legal lending limit for a single borrower approximately $43.0 million as of December 31, 2022, with in-house lending limits based on borrower credit ratings
Liquidity managed through investment portfolio; investments in debt securities, mortgage-backed securities, federal funds, and deposits; includes bank owned life insurance policies generating income

elements.title: Item 1A. Risk Factors and Dividend Considerations

data.value: The text notes that the Federal Reserve may object to a proposed dividend based on safety and soundness concerns. It emphasizes that no insured depository institution may pay a dividend if doing so would result in undercapitalization, and highlights restrictions if the required capital conservation buffer is not maintained.

The section labeled 'Item 1A. Risk Factors' outlines material risks facing the Company. It details credit and lending risks associated with a high exposure to commercial and residential real estate loans, risks of loan defaults, foreclosure risks, and other factors such as economic conditions, real estate tax rates, and regulatory credit concerns that could materially affect the business and financial condition.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Loan and Real Estate Exposures and Credit Loss Allowance

data.value: Expenditures related to real estate ownership, including real estate taxes and maintenance costs, may adversely affect operating expenses.

Commercial and industrial loans expose the institution to higher financial and credit risks due to factors such as limited collateral at liquidation, concentration of loans among a few borrowers, and the size of loan balances.
Adverse economic conditions, including impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic and downturns affecting small-to-midsized businesses, could impair borrowers' ability to repay loans.
The institution had $435.8 million in unfunded credit commitments as of December 31, 2022, with actual borrowing needs historically lower than the contractual amount.

The process for determining the allowance for credit losses (ACL) relies on complex models and assumptions to forecast future loan performance and expected losses, with potential risks if estimates prove inaccurate.

elements.title: Credit Loss Provisions and Environmental Risks

data.value: The document discusses increasing the allowance for credit losses in response to deteriorating economic conditions, including recession, inflation, and worsening loan performance. This could reduce earnings and negatively affect financial condition.
It highlights the subjectivity in determining the allowance for loan losses, the impact of nonperforming loans, and the need for regulatory review and adjustments.
The text also addresses environmental liability risks and the potential adverse impact of climate change on business operations and credit risk.

elements.title: Interest Rate and Liquidity Risks

data.value: The document discusses how changes in interest rates can negatively affect earnings, income, and financial condition. It emphasizes dependency on net interest income, which is sensitive to changes in rates.

Factors such as general economic conditions, competition, and regulatory policies including actions by the Federal Reserve are mentioned. The document also addresses repricing risk, basis risk, and yield curve risk.
Details on the transition from LIBOR to alternative rates like SOFR are provided, including challenges due to differences in rate calculation methods and the impact on financial instruments.
Liquidity risk is highlighted, noting the potential difficulty in funding operations, meeting obligations, and the reliance on deposits amid competitive pressures.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Sources of Funds, Operational & Technological Risks

data.value: Deposits from certain funding sources may be unstable, potentially requiring higher interest rates to attract or retain them and adversely affecting liquidity.
Failure to attract, retain, or replace maturing deposits could harm liquidity and negatively impact interest margins and overall operating results.

The introduction of new lines of business, products, and services (including payment services and BaaS solutions) introduces risks related to process errors, inadequate resource allocation, and compliance with regulatory requirements.

Dependence on operational and technological infrastructures, including challenges with third-party service providers and integration of new systems, may result in system failures, data breaches, or competitive disadvantages.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Operational, Cyber, and Vendor Risks

data.value: Systems and facilities may fail due to uncontrollable events such as spikes in transaction volume, cyber-attacks, or other unforeseen catastrophic events.
Threats include unauthorized access, data breaches, account takeovers, computer viruses, and other malicious actions compromising confidential information.
Dependence on external vendors poses risks; a breach or failure by a vendor could lead to operational disruptions and increased expenses.
Increased reliance on internet-connected systems makes the company vulnerable to cyber criminals and complex attacks.
Existing insurance may not fully cover all losses, damages, or penalties arising from cyber incidents or system failures.
Protective measures include encryption, authentication systems, regular security audits, an incident response plan, and employee training.

elements.title: Cybersecurity and Digital Banking Risk Factors

data.value: The text describes the heightened cybersecurity risks in the financial services industry due to reliance on digital banking products, mobile payments, and cloud-based services.
Cyber-attacks, hacking, malware, ransomware, supply chain attacks, vulnerabilities, credential stuffing, phishing, and social engineering incidents.
Unauthorized transactions, loss or compromise of sensitive/confidential information, reputational damage, legal and financial exposure, and regulatory intervention.

Increasing sophistication of malicious actors, rapid evolution of attack techniques, limitations in monitoring third-party cybersecurity practices, and the difficulty in retaining talent to address cybersecurity challenges.

Investments in enhanced security measures, new technologies for risk mitigation, robust authentication and layered security controls, and cybersecurity insurance, though coverage may not fully offset risks.

elements.title: Risks from Third-Party Services, Reputational Impact, and IP Litigation

data.value: The document highlights that insurance could deny coverage for certain claims or become more expensive, affecting future claims handling.

Reliance on third-party providers for data processing, IT infrastructure, and core application services poses risks. Failures or interruptions in these services could disrupt operations and lead to significant delays and expenses.
Adverse consumer perceptions and external opinions may harm the company's reputation, impacting account origination, maintenance, and leading to potential regulatory scrutiny.
Dependence on information provided by clients and counterparties, which may be inaccurate or fraudulent, exposes the company to risks of financial loss and challenges in recovery.

Potential litigation related to technology and intellectual property rights, including patent infringement claims, could result in protracted, expensive legal battles and significant financial liabilities.

elements.title: Risk Factors and Strategic Risks Disclosures

data.value: The document highlights exposure to credit risk through counterparties and the risk of losses if collateral cannot be realized at adequate prices.
It describes how defaults or even rumors regarding financial institutions can trigger market-wide liquidity issues, potentially leading to losses.
Although pre-pandemic operations have resumed, COVID-19 variants still pose a risk of future operational disruptions.
Strong competition in loans, deposits, and recruiting qualified employees may lead to lower interest margins and reduced profitability.
The company’s ability to grow organically and through acquisitions may be hindered by economic conditions, regulatory changes, and higher levels of nonperforming assets.
Changes in monetary policy and a transition from a low to a rising interest rate environment could increase funding costs before asset yields adjust.
Shifts in business, economic, and political conditions, particularly in the market area, could adversely affect growth and earnings.

elements.title: Risk Factors and Economic Conditions

data.value: Discussion of how general business, economic and political conditions, including inflation, recession, and changes in interest rates and money supply, may adversely affect asset quality, deposits, loan demand, growth and earnings.

Emphasis on risks associated with significant real estate loans, including potential decreases in property values impacting collateral and the ability to sell it upon foreclosure, which could affect profitability.

Explanation of the competitive landscape in financial services, including increased competition from traditional banks, non-bank financial providers, and changing customer needs, which may adversely affect financial performance.

Concerns regarding the need to maintain or raise additional capital due to regulatory requirements and market conditions, which may not be available on acceptable terms, thereby impacting financial condition and operations.

Risks related to operating in a highly regulated environment, including the potential adverse effects of changes in laws, regulations, supervisory actions by entities such as the Federal Reserve, FDIC, and Virginia Bureau of Financial Institutions.

Potential impacts from widespread health emergencies or pandemics, such as COVID-19, including quarantines, business shutdowns, labor shortages, supply chain disruptions, and overall economic instability.

elements.title: Risks Associated with Our Common Stock

data.value: The market price of our common stock may be highly volatile, making it difficult for investors to resell shares at desired volumes, prices, and times.
Various factors such as fluctuations in operating results, economic conditions, changes in credit and housing markets, and regulatory changes can impact stock price and trading volume.
Dividend payments depend on funds received from the Bank and are subject to regulatory and contractual restrictions, which may limit the company's ability to pay dividends consistently.
The company’s common stock is subordinate to preferred stock and subordinated notes, impacting dividend declarations and distributions.
The company benefits from reduced disclosure requirements, which may affect investor perception and its future dividend and executive compensation disclosures.

elements.title: Regulatory Compliance and Property Portfolio Disclosure

data.value: As a public company, the document outlines obligations to prepare and distribute periodic reports, proxy statements, and other shareholder communications in compliance with federal securities laws. It also specifies the expansion of the board's roles and duties, enhanced financial reporting and disclosure procedures, increased involvement of outside counsel and accountants, improved investor relations, new internal policies, retention of additional personnel, Nasdaq listing compliance, and adherence to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

The evolving rules, regulations, and changes in laws are expected to increase legal and financial compliance costs. This could lead to higher administrative expenses and divert management’s time and resources from revenue-generating activities, potentially adversely affecting the business, financial condition, and operating results.

There is uncertainty regarding ongoing compliance due to varying interpretations and evolving regulatory guidance, which may require continuous revisions to disclosure and governance practices and necessitate significant additional expenditures.
The document also provides details on office properties as of December 31, 2022, with net book values of $11.8 million for office properties and $2.3 million for furniture, fixtures and equipment.

A table (titled 'Bank Property Portfolio') presents 6 properties, including details such as location, ownership status (Owned/Lease), year acquired or leased, and the value of real property. For example, the Headquarters at 10089 Fairfax Blvd., Fairfax, VA (Owned, acquired in 2010) has a value of $7.48 million. The portfolio includes 4 owned and 2 leased properties with a total owned property value of approximately $11.79 million.

elements.title: Forward-Looking Statements Disclaimer and Critical Accounting Policies

data.value: The text contains a forward–looking statements disclaimer, listing numerous risk factors that could result in actual results differing materially from those expressed.

Mentions factors such as general economic conditions, inflation, interest rate environment, competition for deposits, adverse changes in securities markets, regulatory changes, integration of acquired entities, changes in consumer habits, accounting policy amendments, employee retention, financial condition and capital adequacy issues, asset quality deterioration, cyber threats, third-party dependencies, loan portfolio performance, and other operational risks.

Discusses the significance of critical accounting policies which include the allowance for loan losses, fair value of financial instruments, and derivative financial instruments. These policies rely on estimates, assumptions, and judgments that may change with new information.
Contains language related to future expectations using words like 'believe', 'expect', 'anticipate', 'intend', as well as conditional verbs such as 'will', 'should', 'could' and similar expressions.

elements.title: Accounting Policies: Loan Loss Allowance, Fair Value, and Derivative Instruments

data.value: Management maintains an allowance for loan losses to absorb estimated probable incurred losses inherent in the loan portfolio. This allowance is comprised of a specific component for impaired loans and a general component for performing and non-classified loans, determined by historical loss experience, migration analysis, current economic conditions, and other qualitative factors.

A portion of the Company's assets and liabilities is carried at fair value. Fair value is determined using quoted market prices where available, or internally developed models using observable market-based parameters. Adjustments are made for factors such as counterparty credit quality and may impact investment securities, real estate owned, and impaired loans.

The Bank records derivative financial instruments such as interest rate swaps at fair value on the balance sheet. These instruments, which include swaps with loan customers and dealer counterparties, are not designated as hedging instruments and resulting unrealized gains and losses are reflected in noninterest income or expense.

elements.title: Loan Impairment, TDR and Allowance for Loan Losses

data.value: A loan is considered impaired when it is probable that the Bank will be unable to collect all interest and principal payments as scheduled. Insignificant delays do not trigger impairment if ultimate collectability is expected.
Impairment is measured on a loan-by-loan basis using the present value of expected future cash flows, the obtainable market price, or the fair value of the collateral if collateral dependent.

Modification of original loan terms due to borrower deterioration. TDRs are considered impaired loans. Loans may remain accruing or nonaccrual based on payment history and revised terms. As of December 31, 2022 and 2021, there were zero loans classified as TDR.

Established through charges to earnings as a provision for loan losses. The allowance covers probable losses based on the difference between the carrying value of the loan and the estimated net realizable value or fair value of the collateral. Subsequent recoveries are credited to the allowance.

Evaluations include trends in delinquencies, charge-offs, economic conditions affecting borrower repayment, and collateral value changes. Specific risks for residential mortgages, construction loans, commercial real estate, and commercial and industrial loans are considered.

elements.title: Loan Classification and Risk Management

data.value: Discussion on consumer secured loans (indirect lending) and the risks associated with the creditworthiness of borrowers and collateral value.

Allowance for loan losses is divided into specific (for impaired loans where collateral value or discounted cash flows are lower than the carrying value) and general components (for non-classified, performing, substandard, or special mention loans).
Appraisals are conducted by independent third-party appraisers based on recent sales, market conditions, and other qualitative factors, with adjustments made as necessary.
Detailed loan classifications including Pass, Watch, Special Mention, Substandard, Doubtful, and Loss rated loans, outlining their risk profiles and mitigation measures.
Explanation of accrual of interest on loans and the process to discontinue accrual, with provisions to return to accrual status under defined conditions.

elements.title: Note 13. Commitments and Contingencies & Note 14. Leases

data.value: The Bank’s financial statements note various commitments and contingent liabilities that involve elements of credit, interest, and liquidity risk. These include commitments to extend credit and the issuance of standby letters of credit.

Loan commitments increased significantly from 304,335 in 2021 to 435,751 in 2022 (a 43% increase) while standby letters of credit decreased from 230 in 2021 to 0 in 2022. All figures are in thousands of dollars.
Financial Commitments (in thousands of dollars)
The note also discloses additional credit commitments made in 2020 and 2022 to various investment funds, with partial funding already deployed and remaining balances noted.
The Bank mentions being involved in various litigation matters incident to normal business practices, which are not expected to have a material adverse impact.

elements.title: Regulatory and Compliance Overview

data.value: The Company is a bank holding company subject to extensive regulation under the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956.
Regulated by Bureau, Federal Reserve, and SEC.
Regulations affecting operations include capital adequacy, loan conditions, and compliance with consumer laws.

elements.title: Deposit Insurance and Regulatory Capital Requirements

data.value: The FDIC insures deposits at federally insured financial institutions like the Bank. Deposit accounts in the Bank are insured by the FDIC generally up to a maximum of $250,000 per separately insured depositor.
The FDIC charges insured depository institutions assessments to maintain the Deposit Insurance Fund.

data.key: Final Rule on Insurance Assessment Rates
data.value: In October 2022, the FDIC adopted a final rule that increased the initial base deposit insurance assessment rate schedules by 2 basis points.
The FDIC has the authority to increase insurance assessments which could have an adverse effect on the operating expenses of the Bank.
The Bank is required to comply with capital adequacy requirements adopted by the Federal Reserve and other federal bank regulatory agencies.
The Basel III Capital Rules require the maintenance of minimum amounts and ratios of Common Equity Tier 1 capital.
Federal bank regulatory agencies are required to take prompt corrective action with respect to institutions not meeting specified minimum capital requirements.

elements.title: Regulatory Compliance and Restrictions

data.key: Tangible equity to total assets ratio
data.value: 2.0% or less, subject to FDIC receiver appointment if capital doesn't improve in 90 days
Bank was compliant with all regulatory capital standards and qualified as 'well-capitalized'
Implements restrictions on transactions between the bank and its affiliates
Banks must meet the credit needs of their entire community

elements.title: Regulatory Compliance and Capital Requirements

data.value: The viability of the banking organization’s operations, ability to deliver banking products and services, and financial sector stability may be materially affected.
Bank service provider must notify affected customers promptly if a security incident materially affects them.
The Bank is required to implement controls for anti-money laundering and verify customer identities.
Violations may incur substantial civil and criminal penalties.
